ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: I would say that it exposes students to a great deal of Renaissance authors. Yet in my opinion, none of these authors are treated in any kind of depth, and often what results is a host of conflicting ideas, unfinished thoughts, and overall confusion. I realize the impossibility of treating authors in depth when, say, we only have a single day budgeted for Machiavelli. Indeed whole courses could be devoted to many of the authors and texts studied. For this reason I found the course to be a disappointment. In my view, it's always better to aim for genuine engagement with primary texts, even at the expense of breadth. Though this might not fully introduce students to the vast discipline of Renaissance studies and might weaken their knowledge of current anglo-american authorities in the field, I would willingly make this sacrifice if only to gain more time for engagement with the likes of Alberti, Ficino, Machiavelli, and others. In sum, because I found the reading assignments too heavy, and the discussions too light, I would not recommend the course to another student.
I would recommend the course to anyone who has an interest in the period and who is willing to engage in in-depth conversations on primary texts.

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: The course was a chance to read critically fundamental texts of the Renaissance period, something which will no doubt greatly benefit my research and professional development in the Renaissance studies programme.
